nodes.bodyText:
Unfortunately I think we can't get around this if/else situation like we did in Core.  We could "wrap" the core percentilesConfig with an xpack config... but internally it'd do essentially the same if/else to delegate to the appropriate agg.
I don't see us extending this code anywhere further so the extra wrapper didn't seem useful.  If we ever decide to build more xpack percentiles/ranks stuff it might make sense though.
That seems fine.   I'm a lot more okay with doing this type of thing when it's serving to maintain isolation between components.
Just double checking - It's okay to remove this here because nothing legacy (multi, array, top metrics, composite) supports histogram fields anyway.

Correct.  Definitely not for multi/array/top_metrics, and composite shouldn't be able to support it because that would only be possible with a percentiles agg inside composite which will resolve separately (either OSS and fail or XPack and succeed).
But... I'm gonna add some tests to verify that. Just in case :)

Couldn't find a way to actually test this, since Core can't use the histo field without the xpack plugin, and testing from xpack doesn't make sense since the field and agg are available.
But I think that confirms that this is ok to remove
The only other user of histo is boxplot which is xpack only too.
the nittiest of nits: multi-line comments should use /* notation
Just curious, why did you choose an assert here instead of an if/throw check?  And do you think we should do that for other places we cast ValuesSources?

Hmm honestly I'm not sure.  Might be a holdover from debugging that I forgot to remove?  It doesn't seem overly useful... if we got here with something other than a histogram we're having a bad day anyway.
I'd be ++ to remove unless we can think of a valid reason for keeping around
Why do we need a new AggregatorSupplier here? Shouldn't we just implement the existing one from core?
Ugh, this is such a mess.  This is all going away in #53198, thank goodness.  I'll try to get that merged today.

:)  My thoughts exactly, happy to see this go away soon. With Histo it's not too bad since it's pretty isolated, but I could see these turning into a real nightmare in the future if there are some things that need to be "castableTo" across plugins or Core.

+1 for using an enum here.  I'm actually about to update the documentation on ValuesSourceType to recommend this pattern.  That said, I'd suggest AnalyticsValuesSourceType as the name, in case we want to add another here later.

/cc @csoulios who I chatted with briefly about this.  I guess it comes down to how we want to organize new VSTypes?  E.g. are they grouped by plugin/module (everything in Analytics goes into one enum), or based on functionality (e.g. Rollup has it's own enum, Histo has it's own, etc)?
Probably doesn't really matter other than being consistent.
